Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will pursue research in prediction of floor vibrations due to human activities. The research plan consists of two parts: (1) a study of the effects of the human-floor system interaction, and (2) a study of floor vibration assessment for human acceptance. To conduct the research, the project will use laboratory experiments, field investigations, and analytical studies. Finite element analytical model will be used to represent the structural system of the floor. Experimental research will be conducted using an existing two-story structure in the Laboratory. The test structure will help the investigators to study the effects of human-structure interaction and assess floor vibrations under a controlled laboratory environment. In addition, parameters for the assessment of floor vibrations for human perception will be studied. A series of field tests and measurements on large floor structures are planned to validate analytical and laboratory results.

The outcome of this research will be of significance to the committees dealing with building serviceability issues as related to floor vibrations. Unacceptable floor vibrations can be a serious serviceability issue for architects, engineers, and building owners. This problem is becoming prevalent due to the use of higher strength materials, use of computer-assisted design to optimize the weight of structural members, rhythmic human activities such as dancing, aerobics, indoor jogging, etc., and innovative designs by architects achieving long, column-free spans resulting in a reduction in the natural frequency and damping. The result is that many floors are susceptible to annoying vibrations requiring expensive retrofitting. In addition, housing of sensitive equipment such as magnetic resonance imaging scanners, electron microscopes, etc., on building floors require very low vibration limits for their proper operations. It is necessary to predict analytically vibration performance of floors when subjected to excitations by human activities. The most important issues in floor vibrations are the dynamic interaction between humans and floor structure and human perception of vibrations

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Excessive vibration problem of civil structures such as building floors, footbridges or monumental stairs are important issues that have become more common in recent years. There are several reasons for this increase in vibration serviceability issues such as use of higher strength building construction materials resulting in smaller member sizes, use of computer-aided design resulting in more optimum and safe structures but susceptible to vibrations, use of large open space areas, and more common spaces for rhythmic activities such as aerobics, dancing, etc.

The main outcomes of this project are:

(1) Evaluation of the effects of humans on the dynamic properties of structural floors (natural frequency and damping ratios), and development of experimentally verified dynamic models of humans that can help with more accurate prediction of structural response. A number of tests on several test floors and footbridges with human subjects in three different postures: standing, sitting, and bent-knees were conducted. A shaker was used and the dynamic responses of the floor without and with people were compared. Mathematical models of the human subjects were developed and included into a computer software along with the building floors. The human dynamic parameters were then changed so that the computed floor responses were close to those from the measurements. Using this method, the dynamic parameters of single-degree-of-freedom and two-degrees-of-freedom human models in different postures were identified.

(2) Development of a performance- (usage-) based approach for the vibration evaluation of commercial building floors and footbridges. In this method, the allowable vibration limits depend on the level of use (i.e., smaller limits for more heavily-used structures). In this research,  dynamic tests on different building floors at two stages of construction (before the placement of non-structural elements and after their installation) were conducted. In addition, several dynamic tests on two footbridges were performed. Using the collected data, relationships between different evaluation parameters were computed and acceptable vibration limits based on the expected number of walk events were established.

(3) Development of ground reaction forcing functions due to human movements in time and frequency domains that can help structural designers to more accurately predict floor vibration response and design more economical structures. A number of human subjects walked over an instrumented force platform to measure their footfall forces. Using a mathematical approach (Fourier Analysis), the components of the applied forces in terms of their harmonic components were computed. The outcome of this study helps structural engineers to more accurately predict floor dynamic response and as a result design more efficient floor structures without vibration serviceability issues.

(4) Development of cost-effective Portable Tuned Mass Dampers (PTMDs) and Multiple Tuned Mass Dampers (MTMDs) to control excessive vibrations of existing and new structures. A number of tests were conducted on two laboratory floors, an existing building floor and a footbridge to check the effectiveness of these devices in reducing vibrations due to human movements. The devices were designed with the aim of reducing their fabrication costs, and facilitating their assembly, installation, and tuning. PTMDs/MTMDs provide economic alternatives to control vibrations of structures without the need to substantially increase the amount of construction materials required to control excessive vibrations of structures due to human movements.

Modified by: Mehdi Setareh

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Excessive vibration problem of civil structures such as building floors, footbridges or monumental stairs are important issues that have become more common in recent years. There are several reasons for this increase in vibration serviceability issues such as use of higher strength building construction materials resulting in smaller member sizes, use of computer-aided design resulting in more optimum and safe structures but susceptible to vibrations, use of large open space areas, and more common spaces for rhythmic activities such as aerobics, dancing, etc. The main outcomes of this project are: (1) Evaluation of the effects of humans on the dynamic properties of structural floors (natural frequency and damping ratios), and development of experimentally verified dynamic models of humans that can help with more accurate prediction of structural response. A number of tests on several test floors and footbridges with human subjects in three different postures: standing, sitting, and bent-knees were conducted. A shaker was used and the dynamic responses of the floor without and with people were compared. Mathematical models of the human subjects were developed and included into a computer software along with the building floors. The human dynamic parameters were then changed so that the computed floor responses were close to those from the measurements. Using this method, the dynamic parameters of single-degree-of-freedom and two-degrees-of-freedom human models in different postures were identified. (2) Development of a performance- (usage-) based approach for the vibration evaluation of commercial building floors and footbridges. In this research, dynamic tests on different building floors at two stages of construction (before the placement of non-structural elements and after their installation) were conducted. In addition, several dynamic tests on two footbridges were performed. A number of human subjects walked over an instrumented force platform to measure their footfall forces. Using a mathematical approach (Fourier Analysis), the components of the applied forces in terms of their harmonic components were computed. The outcome of this study helps structural engineers to more accurately predict floor dynamic response and as a result design more efficient floor structures without vibration serviceability issues. (4) Development of cost-effective Portable Tuned Mass Dampers (PTMDs) and Multiple Tuned Mass Dampers (MTMDs) to control excessive vibrations of existing and new structures. A number of tests were conducted on two laboratory floors, an existing building floor and a footbridge to check the effectiveness of these devices in reducing vibrations due to human movements. The devices were designed with the aim of reducing their fabrication costs, and facilitating their assembly, installation, and tuning. PTMDs/MTMDs provide economic alternatives to control vibrations of structures without the need to substantially increase the amount of construction materials required to control excessive vibrations of structures due to human movements.
